subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals error message
msgSnippet: Ive supplied a patch for the comparison at the junit project at sourceforge (junit.sf.net), but after one reply I ve never heard from the administrators again.
messageBody:
Ive supplied a patch for the comparison at the junit project at sourceforge (junit.sf.net),
but after one reply I've never heard from the administrators again. It has gone almost
a year since I submitted it, but it seems that the junit project is sleeping/freezed.
All though it is a very good tool, but it could be improved with a few minor updates.
(such as mine comparison check, assert equals of arrays, etc).
You can check it out at: http://www.shorl.com/demoprujujegi


The best suggestion that I can make, if you dont want to alter the junit code is
to use the junit addons project. (see JBs post)


But I agree that it would be nice to have this feature in the original junit project since
this is a very common feature request.

//Erik

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Shore
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, October 14, 2003 2:45 AM
Subject: [junit] assertEquals error message


I'm trying to find the right place to ask for a change to JUnit. I hope
this is it. If not, please tell me where to go. :)

In the current version of JUnit, assertEquals displays an edited message
when it fails. This is very frustrating as it makes it difficult for me
to see the source of my errors.

For example, the below test displays this error:

The test:

public void testArrggghhh() {
assertEquals("foobar", "foo bar", "foobar");
}

Displays: "foobar expected: <... ...> but was <......>"

This error message is useless for me. I work around it, of course, but
it's making me go a lot slower. I would like to see this feature turned
off or made more sophisticated by the introduction of more surrounding
context (say, at least ten characters on each side). Any plans to fix
it?

Jim
